Award.AwardTitle: CIF:EAGER:Information Theory Approaches for finding Atypical Sequences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
One characteristic of the information age is the exponential growth of information, and the ready availability of this information through networks, giving the "Big Data" era. Whereas the conventional approach to treating such large volumes of data is through statistics, such as averages, the perspective in this project is the opposite, namely that most of the value in the information is in the parts that deviate from the average, that are unusual, atypical. Familiar examples include valuable paintings or writings that deviate from the norms, that are atypical. The same could be true for venture development and scientific research. The goal of this project is to investigate atypicality both from a theoretical and a practical point of view. The proposed work uses the information theory concept of descriptive length, in a general sense, to characterize atypicality. The project is oriented around two thrusts. The first is a theoretical development to make precise exactly what should be considered atypical from an information theory point of view. The second is algorithm development to implement this theory, and in particular to find fast algorithms for implementation so that big data sets can be processed.

Analysis of large data sets, mainly in biology and medicine, including ECG (electro cardiogram) and genomics, will be used in simulations, as they can lead to new diagnostic methods for human cardiac disease.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has developed methodology and software for finding interesting pieces of information in Big Data. With Big Data the amount of information has become so large that humans cannot look through it all. Based on information theory, we have developed a novel methodology, atypicality, that can extract information that is “unusual” out of data.

What is characteristic of this problem is that we do not know in advance what we are looking for. In Donald Rumsfeld’s infamous words, we are looking for the ‘unknown unknowns.’ We therefore need universal methods for scanning data. Based on some deep results in information theory, we have developed a methodology based on descriptive length. Briefly, we say that data is atypical if it can be described with fewer bits in itself rather than describing it with the best code for typical data. We have tested the methodology on several real world datasets; The attached images show some results.

The broader impact of the methodology has huge potential impact. While the project has only developed the basic methodology, once this is deployed on a large scale, it can for example help medical researchers find new signs of decease, astronomers find new classes of objects, and prevent cybersecurity attacks on computer networks.
